âNiceâ originally meant âfoolishâ (ultimately derived from Latin nescius âignorantâ, from the verb nescire ânot knowâ).Â  In the 19th century, it gained the modern meaning (via several earlier changes), apparently beginning in Britain.Â  The 1864 revision of Websterâs dictionary included the following note in the entry for âniceâ:

Of late, a new sense has been introduced, â¦. namely, pleasing; as, aÂ nice girl, a nice party, a nice excursion, etc. We even hear it for beautiful; as, a nice morning, a nice day, etc. This use of the word, though sanctioned by no lexicographer, is extremely common among the English; and if Americans overdo as to âfineâ, they overdo as to ânice,â but with this difference, that we always give the former its true sense, while they rob the latter of its appropriate and distinctive meaning.

Ignorant people misusing âniceâ!Â  I also like that potshot at what appears to have been contemporary criticism from the English about Americans overusing the word âfineâ.Â  :-) âAt least we give it the right meaning!â

All true, but literally/figuratively still makes me twitch. I am old-fashioned!

Yeah, to be honest, it bugs me too!Â  But, thatâs the nature of language change.Â  :)Â  I mean, âawfulâ originally meant literally âfull of aweâ.Â  I believe it was one of the King Jameses who described a cathedral, with high praise, as âawful and artificialâ, in the meaning âfull of aweâ and âartfully-madeâ.

Oooh, I love that! I use “awesome” a lot, in the modern American sense of “cool”, but I love slipping it in in the sense of “to [terrify/fill] with awe”. I’m going to try to work in “awful” as well, now!
